DIV1.P: NEW BROOMS! AN OCCASIONAL PRELUDE, AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, IN CROW-STREET. BY GEORGE COLMAN.

DUBLIN: Printed for Messrs. PRICE, CORCORAN, W. WATSON, SHEPPARD, J. HOEY, WILKIN∣SON, W. COLLES, WILLIAMS, MON∣CRIEFFE, WALKER, JENKIN, WOGAN, R. STEWART, R. CROSS, HILLARY, J. COL∣LES, BEATTY, TALBOT, AND M'DONNELL. MDCCLXXVII.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE following little Piece was written at the request of Mr. SHERIDAN, who thought that whatever was said of the late Manager, or of his Successors, would come with a better grace from a third person than from the parties concerned. I am happy to have had it in my power to oblige him; and heartily wish that the candour and indulgence, which the Public have shewn to these Scenes, may prove a Prelude to the success of his su∣perior abilities to entertain them. His laurels being yet green from the fame of the DUEN∣NA, revived in my mind the idea of two cha∣racters, Crotchet and Sir Dulcimer Dunder, which it is well known that I had in contem∣plation about twelve years ago, and which were then intended to serve as an introduction to a Comick Opera. The thought proposed for the subject matter of the Prologue, was kindly worked up by a friend, who desired to remain concealed, but whose stile and manner are too familiar to the Stage, not to betray him to the Publick, who will doubtless be pleased to see him disposed, even in his retirement, to contribute to their amusements.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, The Playhouse Passage—the doors just open—various People going to the Play— Coachmen, Chairmen, Constables, Fruit-wo∣men, &c. attending as usual.

SP.P: CH'a some nonpareils! ch'a some fruit, your Honour!—a bill of the Play!—take some fruit——you'll be very dry in the house, sir—a bill of the Play!
Here!—let's see your bill, and sixpenn'orth of apples—takes bill and fruit. Is this the way to the gallery?
Up those steps, sir——bless your honour!—Exit Lad. ch'a some nonpareils!— a bill of the Play!

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. and Mrs. and little Miss Dripping.

SP.P: Lord, lord! I am in a monstrous heat, Mr. Dripping!—such a long walk, all the way from Candlewick-ward!—and then, my dear, your coat's quite spoil'd, and the child's slip all splash'd by the hackney-coaches—here, let me set you to rights, Betsey, before you go among the company.
while Mrs. Drip. is settling her. Dear me! what a sweet place this is!—are the actors all alive, papa?
Alive! ay, alive and merry, I warrant you.
And shall we see Punch, papa?
No,—there's no Punch here, child;— Punch is entirely engaged in the country.
Nay, nay, don't stand prating here, Mr. Dripping;—we shall have lost the first row in the gallery.—Come along, child; come along, Mr. Dripping!Exeunt Drippings.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. and Mrs. Furrow, and Frank Furrow.

SP.P: Lord, feather! how grand they have made the outside of the shew-place!—It's finer than our new Town-house, lately built for their Worships at Sessions, and the Judges at 'Sizes.
But, Mr. Furrow!
What d'ye say, Love?
Sha'n't we see the smart, handsome young fellow, that did Romeor at our town, in July, among the player men?

See him, Love!—Thou may'st see him, and some of the rest on 'em, mayhap—but in another-guess fashion than they were i'th' country.— Romeo—Romeo may sweep the stage, perhaps— and Alexander shift the scenes—and Julius Caesar light the candles.
Why, sure! you don't tell me so!

Very true, Love!—why the R is in the month, wife; and that makes a wonderful difference in the player folks consequence—ay, and in other folks consequence too, Love.— There's the member for our Town, who makes such plaguy long-winded speeches at the Raven, and our hall i'th' country, all summer—all winter i'th' Parliament-house is as mute as an oy∣ster.
Have a care of your pockets, gen∣tlefolks!
'Ecod, that's right—have a care of thy metal watch, Frank!—Mind your pockets, Dame Furrow!— A plaguy pickpocket place, this same play-house, I promise you.Exeunt.

Come along, Moll!—streamers waving, and colours flying!—come along, girl!—away to the launch of Old Druy! — The vessel has been careened and refitted, and a stout crew on board, I hear—but they have lost their old gallant com∣mander—Davy for ever!—Davy for ever!— I wish the new Jacks a fair wind, however!— give them sea-room enough, and—
Ch'a some nonpareils!—a bill of the Play, ma'am!
Oh, I must have some fruit, Jack.— How do you sell them, mistress?
Six for a—

Hark'ee, Moll! don't you be stowing too much sour-crout aboard—it will give you the cholick, mayhap.—Let's see, sweetheart! one, two, three—damme, what signifies reckoning? Here's a full night's pay for you, and we'll seize
the whole cargo takes the basket. Come along, Moll!—Davy for ever!

STAGE.HI: Exit with Doxy, reeling and singing.

SP.P: Oh, by St. Patrick, I am afraid I'll be too late—the house was full before the doors were open, and—
behindPhelim! hola! Phelim!— Phelim turns..

Oh! is it you, Master Catcall? I am glad to see you—that is, I'll be glad another time, d'ye see—but I'm going to the Play this moment, because I know it is too late, and I'll not be able to get in; so I can't stay to spake to you now, unless you'll come a long with me, honey!
Stay, don't be in such a hurry, Phelim, —you're in very good time—there will be room enough, I promise you.

To be sure I don't know bitter, honey! Haven't I taken places, when they were not to be had, no more than a place at Coort? and haven't I stood here in the anti-chamber, on the outside of the house, among all the dear cratures, squeezing and crouding, and squeaking and squawling. and tearing of capuchins, and braking of ligs, and all the sport in nature, honey?
Ay, ay; that was formerly; but the case is alter'd now, Phelim.
Why what's the matter now, honey?

Oh, the Comick Mirror is broke to pieces; that's all, Phelim—It used to shew the
figure of one Manager; but now the fragments re∣flect half a score.
Mirror—and fragments? — dibble burn me if I understand a word that you say, my dear.

Roscius is departed.—The little man has left the house—It used to be full in his time, it is true, Phelim, full as an egg—but he is gone off with the meat, and a whole crew of new Managers are putting to sea in the egg-shell.
Oh, a mighty plisant voyage! good luck to 'em.

Poor devils! What will they do? Not get Half per Cent. for their money—not salt to their porridge. Let me see—who are they?—a Poet, —a Composer of Music—a Practitioner in—What a medley! Ah, little David!

Q.L: To see what I have seen, see what I see!

SP.P: Why, what the divel should you see, but what you do see?—Now, by my sowle, I am glad he is gone.
Glad!
To be sure I am glad. New Brooms, you know—besides, I intind to go upon the stage myself.
laughingWell, that you might have done before, Phelim.
Oh, no such thing, my dear:—the little Man was so grate himself, there was no room for any body else—there is no room for jeanius now.
Yes, more room than company, per∣haps. But, go upon the Stage! are you serious?
Why, where is the joke? What should hinder my going on the Stage, any more than his going off it?
Don't you think that the brogue—
Oh, the brogue's nothing at all, my dear. It's very well known that nobody spakes English so will as your Irishmen—except the Scotch, indeed.
Rather late, at your time of life, for the Stage, however. Consider your age, Phelim.
My age! oh, the oulder the bitter, boy. Don't all your ould actors play the young parts? And how can your young fellows have had any ex∣perience?
Can you boast of any?
Boast? To be sure I can't boast! To be sure I haven't a Shakespeare in my pocket here.
Why, have you?
Oh, yes—he always sleeps with me by day and by night. See here!producing a book.
You're a magazine of literature—a walk∣ing museum, Phelim.

A parfict circulating library!—all plays are the same to me too—And now I'll rade you a spache, extimpore, as well as if I had studied it. Let's see now!—opening the book—Richard the Second— reading—first, second, third or fourth, 'tis all one to Phelim—Richard the Second, reading — ay, well—so much the bitter—we have been boddered so long with Richard the Third, you know.—Now we'll shew little Roscius the difference.Reads with a brogue.
"As in a Theatre the eyes of min,
"After a well-grac'd actor laves the stage,
"Are idly bint on him that inters nixt—" Oh, the devil! this passage is rather mal-a-propos— puts up the book—But I'll make the folks hare me, and luck at me too, I warrant you—here's a fine figure, honey! —none of your little whipper-snapper
Lilliputians—ate up with the gout and the rheumatis—but tall enough for an Irish Brigade, and strong enough to carry a chair.
Well! if you are resolved on the stage, Phelim, your friends must support you.
Oh, an Irishman never wants supporters, man.
Yes; we must recommend you to the Managers, make a party with the audience, and puff you in the papers. You shall have all my inte∣rest both behind the curtain and before it.
Oh! let little Phelim alone for the cur∣tains, honey.

Nothing to be done without such a friend as I, Phelim!—The town knows me well enough, and so do the Managers; I give them a touch now and then in the papers. Dramaticus in the Chroni∣cle, The Observer in the Post, The Elephant in the Paket, the Drury-Lane Mouse, and Covent-Garden Crickt,—all mine, Phelim!
Whew! Two ligs sat upon three ligs! Why, your critick's a parfict caterpillar!

Yes; and my friend Crotchet, the au∣thor too, who is now writing for the house, shall introduce you to the Managers, and give you some instructions; for, you must know, he reckons him∣self a better actor than any one on the stage. As to the Publick, I'll let them know what to think of you. Crotchet lodges in this neighbourhood—ne∣ver mind going to the play—it will not be worth while, I promise you; so keep your money in your pocket, and come along with me to Mr. Crot∣chet's.
By my soule and I will; I am much obliged to you for Mr. Crotchet, and I shall be tree shillings the bitter for you to my dying day, my dear.Exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE changes to Mr. Crotchet's. Crotchet at his harpsichord, accompanying Miss Quaver.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR, by Miss Quaver Quelche d'amore. Piccini.
DIV1.L: The realms of Drury cannot procure ye
So great a fury as Nelly Jones:
For if you sue her, and make love to her,
Howe'er you wooe her, she'll break your bones.

SP.P: after the airVery well, my dear; very well indeed! an agreeable manner, and fine tones! I'll recommend you in the strongest terms to the new Managers; you shall certainly be engaged at a handsome salary, and play a capital part in my new Opera.
You are very good, Mr. Crotchet; and I shall think myself infinitely obliged to you for your kindness.

Not at all, my dear; one kindness brings on another; it will be in your power to shew me a few little civilities in return. You understand me, my love! And I make no doubt but our ac∣quaintance will be mutually agreeable.

STAGE.HI: Smiles, chucks her under the chin, and kisses her band

SP.P: Oh, lit's go back as fast as we came, frind! Don't you see we shall interrupt the jon∣tleman?
Not in the least: pray walk in, gentle∣men! Mr. Catcall, I rejoice to see you. Have I the honour of knowing this gentleman? a friend of your's, I suppose, Mr. Catcall!
He is, Sir, and extremely ambitious of your friendship and acquaintance. Mr. Crotchet! Mr. Phelim!Introducing them to each other.
taking Phelim by the handSir, I shall be happy to be known, Sir, to any friend, Sir, of my friend, Mr. Catcall's, Sir; and I shall be proud to serve you, Sir!
And I'll be proud too, my dear; and as to sarvice, by my soule you may go to sarvice im∣mediately.
How can I be of use to you, Sir?
Mr. Phelim hopes for your interest with the new Managers of the Theatre, sir.
In what line, sir? as an author, or—
He flatters himself he has some talents for acting.
You may say that; I do flatter my∣self.
Talents for acting?—Lack-a-day, gen∣tlemen! acting—acting's all over now.
The divil it is!—what, is the play∣house burnt down, or shut up, then?

No—but plays are worn out, sir.— Otway's a rag, Jonson obsolete, and Shakespeare worn threadbare. Plays!—plays might do well enough formerly indeed; but quite out of fashion now, sir. Plays and little Roscius left the stage to∣gether, sir.
What will the stage do then?

Do?—Musical pieces, to be sure— Operas, sir—our only dependance now.—We have nothing for it now but wind, wire, rosin and catgut. This is the thing—this is the thing— thrumming on the harpschord Have you any voice? Can you sing, sir?

Voice! oh, by my sowle, voice enough to be heard acoss the channel, from the Gate or the Hid, to ould Dublin:—and then I can sing, Arrah my Judy, Arrah my Judy! and the Irish
howl—Hubbub-o-boo! howling—oh, it would do your heart good to hear it.
Should be glad of that pleasure, sir; a little song now by way of specimen!
Oh, you're as welcome as the flowers in May, my jewel. Him! him!sings.
Well, sir, that may do very well intro∣duced into a Comic Opera.
An Irishman in an Opera! Oh, my dear!

And why not, sir?—Operas are the only real entertainment. The plain unornamented Drama is too flat, sir. Common dialogue is a dry imitation of Nature, as insipid as real conversation; but in an Opera, the dialogue is refreshed by an Air every instant.—Two gentlemen meet in the Park, for example, admire the place and the weather; and, after a speech or two, the orchestra take their cue, the musick strikes up, one of the characters takes a genteel turn or two on the stage, during the symphony, and then breaks out—

Q.L: Warm the heart that sorrow freezes.

STAGE.HI: Singing and walking, as described in his speech.

SP.P: Oh! these airs are mighty refreshing in∣deed, as you say.

No other chance for success now, I promise you, sir.—The Managers know that well enough—they know how many thousand pounds were got last year by the Highland Laddy, and Gra∣machree, sir!—a-a-aquavering And brothers in the young!—that's the mark, sir.
I am glad to hear we are to have an Opera of yours, Mr. Crotchet, this season,
You are, sir; and I have got the finest unnatural thought for it!—
Natural, you mean, Mr. Crotchet.

Natural? I thought you knew better, Mr. Catcall. Nature has nothing to do with an O∣pera—nor with the stage neither, now little Roscius has left it—we shall go quite upon another plan now, sir▪—What do you think I call my Opera?
Can't guess.
Nothing in Nature, to be sure, my jewel.
No, sir; I reverse nature. My Opera is called, sir, is called—
Oh! it has been called long enough. I wish it was coming.
It is called then, sir—
Arrah, what?
Topsy-Turvy.
The wrong side uppermost?

Yes, sir—Topsy-Turvy—that's the ti∣tle of it—the scene, an island in the Antipodes, where the women are paramount, and the men are in subjection.—The ladies judge, fight, swear, drink, ravish, et caetera; and the gentlemen knit, spin, scold, pout, and so forth. At the opening of the piece, after a soft overture, the curtain rises to slow musick, the Lady Chancellor and the Field Marshal being just brought to bed upon which—
Sir Dulcimer Dunder desires to see you, sir.
Desire Sir Dulcimer to walk up.
Sir Dulcimer Dunder! He is a great connoisseur in musick—is not he?
He is—but as deaf as a Post.
Pity he is not blind, that he might be a connisure in pictures too.
Oh, as to that, sir—but he's here.
Say no wore, then—walls may have ears, you know.
Sir Dulcimer, I am happy to have the honour of seeing you
Your Servant, Mr. Crotchet; gentlemen, your servant. They tell me, Mr. Crotchet, there is some mighty pretty musick in your new opera— I should be glad to hear some of it.
I belave yoo'd be glad to hare any thing.— Pray now, Sir Dulcimer, will you give me lave to ax you a little quistion?
Sir?
Will you give me lave to ax you a quis∣stion! bawling
Stay, sir, one moment, if you please— produces a hearing-trumpet, and applies it to his ear. —Now, sir!—what were you saying, sir?
What the divil? am I to talk into that saucepan?
Sir Dulcimer never converses without it. 'Tis his constant companion.
A very necessary Vade Mecum, you see.
to PhelimWhat was it you were say∣ing, sir?
May I be so bould as to ax you, Sir Dul∣cimer, how you came to be so fond of musick, when you are so hard of haring, sir?
Oh there's nothing at all extraordinary in that, sir.
The divil, there isn't!
Nothing at all, sir—It is a mighty com∣mon thing for deaf persons to gain the power of hearing by what stuns other people. Lady Towzer, for instance—you know Lady Towzer?
I have hard of such a lady.

Well, Lady Towzer could never hear but in a mill. The clack of common conversation made no sort of impression on her. And Lord
Thickness, for the very same reason, built his fine new house over against a trunk-maker, and next door to a pewterer.
An agreeable neighbourhood!
And, I, sir, that can scarce hear the guns at the Tower without the help of this trumpet, always put it up at a Concert.
With or without 'tis all the same thing, I suppose.

Handel's thunder strikes upon the nerve like electricity; the ear-piercing fife serves for a syringe;—nay, I should not lose a single demi-semi∣quaver of a solo on the flagelet.—Musick, sir, mu∣sick plays on the drum of my ear, like the wind on an Aeolian harp, sir.
By my soule, Sir Dulcimer, if that was my case now, I would have a barrel of musick always before me—or I would live in an organ—or take lodgings in a bass viol.
Sir Dulcimer has a very nice ear for mu∣sick I promise you.
Mr. Crotchet have you adapted Sir John Suckling's words to the tune I composed for your Opera?
I have Sir Dulcimer.
This lady sings, I suppose. She'll be so good as to favour us with it. Now you shall see, Mr. Phelim!putting up his trumpet.
Come, Miss Quaver!
Lord, I can't sing his frightful tune, sir—but the words will go very well to another—and I dare say he won't know the difference

DIV2.STAGE: Sings, and Sir Dulcimer affects to beat time.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR. La Schiavetta. Piccini. (The Words altered from Suckling)

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Why so pale and wan, fond lover?
Prithee, tell me, why so pale?
Ah, forbear, forbear to teaze her!
If your looking well won't please her,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Why so dull and mute, young sinner?
Girls laugh at a raw beginner—
Prithee, tell me, why so mute?
If you're speaking well won't win her,
Sure the devil must be in her

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Cease for shame! this cannot move her:
She'll scorn such a whining lover—
Drink about, and let's be gay!
If good humour cannot make her,
Better let the devil take her—
Take her and your love away.

SP.P: after the songVery well, very well indeed, ma'am—a great deal of taste—and very neat execution!—But the band was not quite so cor∣rect—we'll try it again, if you please—and hark'ee, gentlemen to the orchestra please to begin a little more piano—then, after ten or twelve bars, forte! —then piano again—then pianissimo—then fortissimo, then—
speaking from the orchestraThat was not your Air we play'd, Sir Dulcimer.
What was it you observed, Sir? applying his trumpet.

STAGE.HI: Sir Dulcimer rather louder than before

SP.P: I know it is a very difficult Air, and you never play'd it before—but if you will only—
clapping his hands on each side of his mouth and bawlingI say that the Air we play'd, and the lady sung, was another Air—and not the Air that you composed, Sir Dulcimer.

Another air?—not my air?—you play'd another Air, gentlemen!—And you sung another Air, ma'm!—You're a set of scraping, piping, impertinent puppies, gentlemen!—And you're a saucy minx, ma'am!—And you have used me very ill, Mr. Crotchet!—and I wish your Opera may be damned—I'll be damned if I don't, sir!Exit in a passion.
A very nice ear for musick Sir Dulcimer has; he can hare a tune that's invisible.
After all, he's a very worthy friendly man, and I am sorry they have affronted him. Ha! Monsieur Mezzetin!—and Sprightly too!
Crotchet! what have you done to Sir Dulcimer Dunder? I met him hobbling out of your house in a most terrible fury.
A little musical accident!
Oh! there's always quarrelling and uproor among you lovers of harmony.
Quarrelling! what has been the matter then?
Sir Dulcimer happened to beat time a little irregularly—that's all.
Yes, he bate time out of doors, my dear; and then took himself out o'doors in the bargain.
I am sorry he is gone. He is a charac∣ter—and I had reserved a niche for him in my Co∣medy.
I heard you were about one,—Mon∣sieur Mezzetin, you seem lame—have you hurt your∣self?
Ver mosh, I assure you, Mr. Croché! I have hurt-a my leg ver mosh in writing un grand ballet for de new danseurs & danseuses engage dis sa∣son at Dury-lane.
What! do you write with your lift lig, my dear? I niver hard of any body writing with their ligs, since the shew-fillow, that wrote a fine hand with his feet, at Charing-Cross.

Oh, begar, you mos stirra your stomp in writing de danse—jambe en l'air, plume a la main —De new troupe vil make a deir debut in von grande Pantomime.—I ave compose de tout.—De scenes, machines, chansons, & decorations are all redy —and Le Docteur Gamut did promiss to meet-a me here to-night vid de musique.
We have seen nothing of him yet, Mon∣sieur Mezzetin.
Oh, begar, il faut depécher.—Dere is no time to be lose— for vidout my pantomime de new directeurs must be ondone.
I thought what the stage would come to —Good night to poor Shakespeare!

Vat signify your trisle Sha-kes-peare? Begar, dere vas more móneys got by de gran spectacle of de Sha-kes-peare Jubilee, dan by all de Comique and Tragique of Sha-kes-peare beside, ma foi!—You make-a de danse, and de musique, and de pantomime of your Sha-kes-peare, and den he do very vell.
Treason! high treason against the Majesty of Shakespeare, and the Empire of the Publick!
That's right, Mr. Sprightly!—shew yourself an advocate for the old sterling Drama— the staple commodity of the Theatre.
There is no occasion for me to plead its cause, sir—ad populum provoco—I appeal to the feelings and good sense of the people.

We know that you are a writer of Comedy yourself, Sprightly—Success attend you! —but believe me, Sprightly, Dramatick Pieces, unadorned by dance and scenery, and unenlivened by musick, will never be able to make a stand against Opera and Pantomime. All men have eyes and ears; but all men have not the like un∣derstandings.

Englishmen, Mr. Crotchet, English∣men consider their eyes and ears as the inlets of in∣struction, as well as entertainment. The stage is the region of enchantment, I grant you. Shew and sing song may be admitted as garnish—the mere lace and fringe of the theatre—but the main body of the stage entertainments should be wrought out of the loom of Shakespeare and his noble assistants. The old Drama, Opera, and Pantomime, may indeed dance the hayes on the stage, like the sun, moon, and earth in the rehearsal—sometimes one in eclipse, and sometimes another. Opera or Pantomime may for a season cause a temporary obscurity, as the dull earth may now and then stand in its own light; but Tragedy and Comedy, like the Sun and Moon, will continue to be the life, delight, and chief support of the English Theatre.
Well said, little Bayes, egad!
By my soule he has so boddered me with eyes and ears, and eclipses, that I am quite in the dark, my dear.

Nay, Gentlemen, Comedy, is no Prude, and I am no Cynick in Theatricals, I pro∣mise you—A clear stage, and fair play for all par∣ties! that's all that is required—These too I can venture to assure you are the sentiments of the new Managers—and if you please, 'Ill speak you a Prologue I have written at their instance for the opening of the Theatre.
Prologue, Prologue, Prologue!
Then silence! We'll suppose the au∣dience to be there, if you please.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: Scribblers are Sportsmen; and as Sportsmen are,
Some hit, some miss, some poach, and some beat fair;
This wounds a straggling bird; that often tries,
But never kills; he shoots and shuts both eyes:
Like our Train'd Bands, the mark he never hits—
He scorns to see the murder he commits;
Some will whole coveys take, nineteen in twenty!
And then you smack your lips—for game is plenty.
In short, by you their merits must be tried—
And woe to them, who are not qualified!
Another simile we mean to broach—
A new one too!—The Stage is a Stage-Coach.—
A Stage-Coach!—why?—I'll tell you if you ask it—
Boxes.Here some take places, and some mount the basketGallery..
Our Cattle too, that draw the Stage along,
Are of all sorts and sizes—weak and strong,
Brown, grey, black, bay, brisk, tame, blind, lame, lean, old and young!
If as we're jogging on, we sometimes stop,
Some scold within, and some asleep will drop,
While sailors and their doxies sing and roar o'top!
The Coachman Manager will sometimes please ye—
But shou'd he stuff the Coach too full, and squeeze ye,
You then begin to swear— "Zounds! shut the door,
"We're cramm'd already—here's no room for more—
"You're so damn'd fat—a little farther, Sir!
"Your elbow's in my stomach—I can't stir."
Hoit! Hoit! the Coachman then drives on apace,
And smack! with other stages runs a race.
Thro' thick and thin we dash, now up, now down,
Now raise a dust, now rattling thro' the Town;
Now first, now last, now jolted, crack! we fall.
Laugh'd, pelted, hooted at, and damn'd by all!
Your late Old Coachman, tho' oft splash'd by dirt,
And out in many a storm, retires unhurt;
Enjoys your kind reward for all his pains,
And now to other hands resigns the reins.
But the new partners of the old Machine,
Hoping you'll find it snug, and tight and clean,
Vow that with much civility they'll treat you,
Will drive you well, and pleasantly will seat you,
The road is not all turnpike—and what worse is,
They can't insure your watches or your purses;
But they'll assure you, that their best endeavour
Shall not be wanting to obtain your favour;
Which gain'd—Gee up! the Old Stage will run for ever!

DIV1.P: Just Published, Price 3d. MAY-DAY; OR THE LITTLE GIPSEY. A FARCE. ALSO, THE HOTEL, OR, THE DOUBLE VALET. A FARCE.
